newsitem.title: JAPAN: New Japan finance minister vows reform of ministry.
newsitem.headline: New Japan finance minister vows reform of ministry.

text.p: Japan's newly appointed Finance Minister Hiroshi Mitsuzuka vowed on Thursday to carry out swift and effective reform of his powerful ministry.
"Administrative reform is the voice of the people and something which will shape Japan's future," Mitsuzuka said in his first news conference as finance minister.

Mitsuzuka said Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto asked him to concentrate particularly on the reform of his ministry, the central bank and the country's entire financial system, on the basis of a policy agreement his Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) signed last week with the Social Democrats and Sakigake -- the two parties now in a loose alliance with the LDP.
Mitsuzuka also pledged to carry out Hashimoto's request for fiscal reform and to promote Tokyo financial markets to make them equal to those of the United States and Europe.

Asked how he will trim the power of over-zealous bureaucrats in his ministry, Mitsuzuka said: "Pure confrontation will be bad, but I will say what I must say. I will welcome what they have to say and that's the way to do it."
